big_picture: The Indian government continues to address pressing national concerns, with Home Minister Amit Shah leading a discussion on cybercrime prevention and response. Meanwhile, the Supreme Court has reaffirmed the limitations of magistrate power to order online content takedowns under Section 69 of the IT Act, following a Bombay High Court ruling. The government remains cautious in assessing the potential impact of US tariff changes on India, with Finance Minister Sitharaman choosing not to comment on the matter. Additionally, the Supreme Court has remanded a challenge to the 27% OBC quota to the Madhya Pradesh High Court for an expedited decision.

articles.title: India overhauls GDP data to improve accuracy, official says
articles.summary: India is set to revise its real GDP calculation methodology this week, incorporating a more granular approach using 500-600 price items from CPI and WPI to enhance accuracy. This overhaul addresses economists' concerns about outdated methods and aims to improve data reliability, particularly for manufacturing. A new GDP series with a 2022/23 base year will be released on February 27.

articles.title: India, China among winners after US court blocked Trump tariffs

articles.title: Trump eyes Section 301 probes as tariff backup: What it means for global trade and why it matters
articles.summary: America's trade chief signals new investigations under Section 301. This law allows action against unfair foreign trade practices. Probes could cover industrial policies, drug pricing, digital trade, and ocean pollution. Such moves could lead to new tariffs or trade restrictions. This signals a potential return to aggressive trade enforcement by the US.
